Lets take a look at a riddle.

##Q1: Equal Product of ℤ 1 - 20

Question

Your given a bag filled with the integers (ℤ) 1 - 20 inclusive. Your tasked with spilitting these Integers into 2 sets such that the product of Set A and Set B are equal. Is it possible to fulfill your task (Split them up according to the rules mentioned above) or is this task impossible.

Answer

âš ï¸ Spoiler Alert.. Always try to solve the riddles yourself first âš ï¸

The task is impossible. We can prove this through a proof by contradiction.

Imagine you were able to split up the first 20 Integers into 2 sets such that the product of Set A and the product of Set B are equal. We can say that the product of Set A is equal to ğ’ and the product of Set B is equalt to ğ’

So we have,

∏

Set A = ğ’
∏ Set B = ğ’

Since we are assuming we are able to complete this task, we can write ğ’ = ğ’

We know from Number Theory that every number has a Unique Prime Factorization. This just means that we can write any number as a product of primes and that there is only 1 way to do so.

What follows from this is that the Unique Prime Factorization of ğ’ must be the same Unique Prime Factorization as ğ’. This ends up being impossible.

Notice how 19 is a Prime.

This means that 19 is either in Set Aâ€™s Factorization or Set Bâ€™s Factorization but NOT BOTH

This means that Set Aâ€™s Factorization is different from Set Bâ€™s Factorization which means

∏

Set A â‰  ∏ Set B â—¼ï¸
